text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.22.5, Mail and Transportation Management, Mail Operations.
1.22.5.1.6, Frequently Used Terms and Acronyms, Acronyms: updated Acronyms table.

ervices request to register with Postal & Transport Policy Section to use carrier’s website to generate shipping labels. (

) Editorial changes have been made throughout the IRM to adhere to plain writing standards.
1.22.5.3, Deﬁnitions of Mailrooms and Mail Operations, (3) changed procedure to contact the LPOC or designee for assistance rather than send the mail piece to them.
1.22.5.13.3 (2), Handling Undeliverable Mail, updated the title for Letter 2797, from “Undeliverable Mail System Update” to “We Need Your Assistance in Updating Your Address Information”
Editorial changes have been made throughout the IRM to adhere to plain writing standards.
IRM 1.22.5, Mail Operations, dated January 14, 2021 is superseded.

) Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS)/Office of the Deputy Director Facilities Support/Logistics: a. Oversees the operation of the Mail Management program. b. Establishes a Territory Point of Contact (TPOC) who provides mail man- agement program guidance for mailroom operations and mail services within their Territory. c. Coordinates Servicewide ﬁeld office mailroom operations and mail delivery services d. Serves as the COR for the National Mailroom Services Contract, and National Postal Meter Contract e. Communicates changes in policy to ﬁeld offices f. Provides TPOCs with training and education (

) Business Operating Divisions (BOD) assign Local Points of Contact (LPOC) IRS Field offices that are not serviced by the Primary Mail Contractor. The LPOC serves as the primary contact for the FMSS Mail Program TPOC.
) Management Review (
) Effective use of the Mail Transportation program services requires a coordina- tion of efforts between the PTP Office, FMSS HQ Mail Program Office TPOCs, and ﬁeld office LPOCs. (

) This IRM describes the different types of mail operations and delivery methods used by the IRS. These descriptions apply to incoming and outgoing mail. PTP section gauges the effectiveness of the descriptions and their use based on feedback from customers, and program owners. During review and publish- ing of the IRM, PTP revises, adds, or removes sections based in part on this feedback, as well as USPS policy changes.

ervices requests

Mailrooms and Functions Mailrooms Functions Submission Process- ing Center/Campus mailrooms Staffed by IRS employees and provide mail service for the Center/Campus and all locations assigned to the Center/Campus. In this type of mailroom: • The staff will typically serve multiple buildings • USPS mail is prepared using a postage metering system • Mail for SPCs will be prepared using Form 9814, Request for Mail/Shipping Service. The form is available at http:// publish.no.irs.gov/cat12.cgi?request=CAT1&catum=22023 Note: Open mail addressed to Submission Processing Center/Campus Operations in Receipt and Control or other desig- nated areas before distribution within the building(s). See IRM 1.22.3.2.1, Unique Zip Code Addresses at http:// irm.web.irs.gov/Part1/Chapter22/ Section3/IRM1.22.3.aspx for a listing of addresses served by a Center/ Campus mailroom.
Mailrooms and Functions

Functions Process- Center/Campus Staffed by IRS employees and provide mail service for the Center/Campus and all locations assigned to the Center/Campus. In this type of mailroom: • The staff will typically serve multiple buildings • USPS mail is prepared using a postage metering system • Mail for SPCs will be prepared using Form
, Request for Mail/Shipping Service. The form is available at http:// publish.no.irs.gov/cat
cgi?request=CAT
&catum=
Note: Open mail addressed to Submission Processing Center/Campus Operations in Receipt and Control or other desig- nated areas before distribution within the building(s). See IRM
, Unique Zip Code Addresses at http:// irm.web.irs.gov/Part
/Chapter
/ Section
/IRM
aspx for a listing of addresses served by a Center/ Campus mailroom.

Mailrooms Functions Contract Mailrooms Found in ﬁeld office locations with 250 or more employees and staffed by contractor personnel monitored by FMSS. In this type of mailroom: • USPS mail is prepared using a postage meter • Mail for SPCs will be prepared using Form 9814, Request for Mail/Shipping Service Shared Mailrooms Found in smaller Posts-of-Duty (POD) with 20 - 250 employees. The mailroom is the desig- nated location that serves all IRS occupied space within the building. Mailroom duties are assigned/shared by the occupying IRS business units and are the responsibility of all occupants regardless of grade or position. In this type of mailroom: • USPS mail is prepared using a postage meter • Mail for the SPC will have an electronic shipping label generated through the SPC website. Employees creating their own shipping labels must still be aware of the shipping instructions contained on page 2 of Form 9814, Request for Mail/Shipping Service. POD Mailrooms PODs with less than 20 employees generally will not have an enclosed mailroom. In this type of location: • USPS mail is prepared using a postage meter or postage stamps. • Mail for the SPC will have an electronic shipping label generated through the SPC website. Employees creating their own shipping labels must still be aware of the shipping instructions contained on page 2 of Form 9814, Request for Mail/Shipping Service. Note: A designated BOD office space may include a mail/copy area. The POD mailroom is the location where delivery and processing of all POD mail occurs. Offices that have a separate mail/copy area will not be assigned an additional postal meter, SPC drop-off or pick-up. (3) Mail operations and functions include receiving, opening, date stamping, sorting, routing, controlling and following up on delayed mail shipments. The 1.22 Mail and Transportation Management

Mail operations and functions include receiving, opening, date stamping, sorting, routing, controlling and following up on delayed mail shipments. The LPOC opens incoming mail according to local procedure and sorts to the

extent possible. When there is insufficient information to sort the mail the LPOC or designee contacts the TPOC or local designee to assist in fying an intended recipient. Mail erroneously delivered to any IRS office different address from the IRS location (e.g., addressed to XYZ Corp), not be opened. Promptly return the misdirected mail to the carrier, whether USPS or SPC and bring to the attention of the LPOC/TPOC. (
) Mandated by the Deputy Commissioner of the IRS in
, all mail is to opened in a centralized mail room or in the official designated mail opening area. (
) Opening mail in centralized mail rooms or officially designated mail opening areas provides for the safety and security of all employees. (
) There are several types of incoming mail: • USPS Accountable Mail • USPS First-Class Mail/Packages • SPC Letters and Packages • Courier (Messenger) Mail • Freight Shipments

extent possible. When there is insufficient information to sort the mail piece, the LPOC or designee contacts the TPOC or local designee to assist in identi- fying an intended recipient. Mail erroneously delivered to any IRS office with a different address from the IRS location (e.g., addressed to XYZ Corp), should not be opened. Promptly return the misdirected mail to the carrier, whether USPS or SPC and bring to the attention of the LPOC/TPOC.
Mandated by the Deputy Commissioner of the IRS in 2001, all mail is to be opened in a centralized mail room or in the official designated mail opening
Opening mail in centralized mail rooms or officially designated mail opening areas provides for the safety and security of all employees.
Note: Each type of mail must be received, counted, logged, and/or sorted.

) USPS delivers Accountable Mail (e.g., Registered, Certiﬁed and Return Receipt Mail) to the addressee or the addressee’s authorized representative. The employee or mail contractor receiving the mail will verify its receipt by signing and dating the PS (Postal Service) Form
, Domestic Return Receipt. A copy of this form will be kept by the mailroom. (

) Upon receipt of the Registered and/or Certiﬁed Mail, the receipts attached the mail piece are removed, date stamped and sent to the Post Office. The envelope is held in the mail area for the addressee or the designee’s signature. (

) USPS delivery of all First-Class Mail is dependent on the type of delivery associated with a particular address. USPS delivers to street addresses, Office (P.O.) Boxes, cluster mailboxes, door slots, or wall mounted centralized mailboxes. (

) SPC deliveries are accountable mail. The SPC will deliver incoming packages and letters to the POD mailroom. The employee or mail contractor will verify receipt of the letters and/or packages by signing the SPC delivery pad. Employees should not accept letters and/or packages from a SPC without signing for receipt of delivery. (
) Courier deliveries are accountable mail and require a signature by the employee who veriﬁes and receives the delivery.
Courier deliveries are accountable mail and require a signature by the employee who veriﬁes and receives the delivery.
) Freight Shipments (

) Shipments made via a freight carrier are more controlled. If building security permits, the shipment may be delivered directly to the individual ﬂoor/room/ suite as an “inside delivery.” The driver will drop the shipment at the dock inside the ﬁrst door if there is no “inside delivery”.
) Postage Due Mail/Collect Delivery (

) “Postage Due” or “Collect on Delivery” mail will be refused when a carrier to deliver such mail. The carrier will endorse the mail item returned for addi- tional postage and return the mail item to the sender. (

) If an IRS office receives mail from another IRS office with postage due, the mail will be accepted and any postage due must be paid through an Official Mail Accounting System (OMAS) postage due account.
, Document Transmittal (
) All mail accompanied by a Form
, Document Transmittal, available at http://publish.no.irs.gov/cat
cgi?request=CAT
&catnum=
will be re- ceived and forwarded to the recipient. The recipient will check the contents against the transmittal document, verify and sign/date the form. (
) The recipient will return a signed acknowledgement copy of the transmittal the sending office via EEFax or scan/email.
) Remittance Mail (
) Remittance mail should be forwarded in accordance with established Business Operating Division (BOD) procedures.
) Handling Personal Mail (

) The personal use of mail products and/or services by IRS employees is not allowed. a. Personal use includes the mailing of job applications, resumes or similar material that do not meet the deﬁnition of Official Mail. Note: Official Mail is mail sent by agencies of the U.S. Government contains matter related exclusively to the business of the United States that is authorized by law to be transmitted in the mail without the prepayment of postage. b. A Government travel card bill is a personal matter and Government cannot be used to mail such payment. c. Personal mail is not allowed to be sent or received by IRS mailrooms. d. For further information, go to: > http://publish.no.irs.gov/mailtran/permail.html for intranet page, Personal Mail >

) Place the term ‘Consolidated Shipment’ on the address label when sending consolidated shipment. Documents System (
) The IMDDS is a method used to distribute IRMs and other miscellaneous products directly to an IRS office. (

) IMDDS consolidates all products delivered to an IRS office. a. Shipments will come consolidated in a box(es) addressed to the building if a product is to be distributed to multiple order points b. IMDDS shipments are recognizable by the name “IMDDS Coordinator” the return address c. The box(es) are opened in the designated mail opening location and inner contents will be distributed, as labeled, to the individual(s) or group(s) (

) Consolidated mail is much like IMDDS shipments but is limited to receipt by larger locations. a. A consolidated mail shipment will contain several envelopes/packages addressed to locations throughout the building(s) b. A consolidated mail shipment contains “Consolidated Shipment” in the address line c. A consolidated mail shipment opened in the designated mail opening location and the inner contents distributed, as labeled, to the individual(s) or group(s) Services (
) When possible, documents and correspondence should be sent via EEFax scanned and transmitted via secure email to eliminate agency shipping/mailing cost. (

) The USPS is the primary carrier for official correspondence and packages going to taxpayers. The Private Express Statutes gives the USPS the exclusive right to carry letters for compensation, with certain limited exceptions. (
) Correspondence and packages shipped between IRS offices and containing processed remittances will use the following shipping guidelines as deﬁned the instructions for Form
, Request for Mailing/Shipping Services. a. Thirteen ounces or less will be shipped via USPS b. More than
ounces will be sent using a SPC ground service c. If shipping more than
boxes or over
pounds to one destination, freight options must be considered to determine the most cost-effective method. (

1.22 Mail and Transportation Management
Note: Items such as personnel ranking packages and training material should always use ground services.
) Due to security concerns, employees teleworking must never receive corre- spondence directly from taxpayers at their residence. (
) Employees on Telework schedule who regularly report to their POD at least once a week will receive mail and packages at their POD. (

) Employees on Telework should plan to send mail and packages on the days they report to their regular POD or another IRS location. If the mailing cannot wait until the employee is in the office, the employee must deposit the mail or package in a secure carrier receptacle (e.g., drop box) or at an authorized shipping outlet.
Due to security concerns, employees teleworking must never receive corre- spondence directly from taxpayers at their residence.
Caution: Security and disclosure concerns prohibit the mailing of official correspon- dence from an employee’s residential mailbox.
Employer and Employees responsibilities for Incoming Mail
Incoming Mail Responsibilities
For purposes of receiving mail from outside the IRS, employees in the H
program will not use their home address as their mailing address. IRS will provide employees with an IRS adminis- trative address where all mail addressed to the employee will be handled.
Employees are prohibited from signing a release that permits private delivery carriers to leave PII and/or SBU shipments unat
tended on a porch, doorstep, or other location outside the home.
For Outgoing Mail: a. When employees must send outgoing correspondence, they may use email if such usage is appropriate, and in accordance with IRM
, Standard for Using Email, which prohibits including taxpayer, PII, and/or SBU information in emails without the use of encryption. More informa- tion on IRM
is available at http://irm.web.irs.gov/Part
/Chapter
/ Section
/IRM

aspx. b. The employees must send all taxpayer correspondence via USPS. Em- ployees will use existing office procedures to procure postage stamps mailing. The administrative office address assigned to the employee be used as the return address for outgoing mail. The mail must be hand- delivered to a USPS carrier, deposited in a secure receptacle, or hand delivered to a clerk at a USPS walk-in counter. c. Use a private delivery carrier such as UPS when shipping to an IRS ad- ministrative address or another federal/state agency. To generate ship- ping labels electronically on the designated private delivery carrier’s website, employees must register with the IRS Postal and Transport Policy Section by submitting an KISAM OS Ge

ervices request. Deliver outgoing packages to a UPS store or deposit in a secure UPS drop box. The employee must obtain pre-approval from their supervisor and the IRS Postal and Transport section to schedule private delivery carrier dential pick ups. d. Employees may not leave mail or packages unsecured on a porch, door- step, or other location outside their home. Include a mail delivery code (e.g., mail stop, office symbols and/or room number) in the return address of any envelope or label on all outgoing mail identify the sending office in the event the item is returned. All outgoing mail is to be taken to the mailroom to be sorted, consolidated, packaged as necessary and postage applied for mailing or shipping by the USPS or other authorized carrier. Employees teleworking should plan to send mail on the days they report to their regular POD or another IRS location. If the mail cannot wait until the employee is in the office, the employee must deposit the mail or package in secure carrier receptacle (e.g., drop box) or at an authorized shipping outlet.

) Include a mail delivery code (e.g., mail stop, office symbols and/or room number) in the return address of any envelope or label on all outgoing mail to identify the sending office in the event the item is returned. (
) All outgoing mail is to be taken to the mailroom to be sorted, consolidated, packaged as necessary and postage applied for mailing or shipping by the USPS or other authorized carrier. (

) Employees teleworking should plan to send mail on the days they report to their regular POD or another IRS location. If the mail cannot wait until the employee is in the office, the employee must deposit the mail or package in a secure carrier receptacle (e.g., drop box) or at an authorized shipping outlet.
Note: Security and disclosure concerns prohibit the mailing of official correspon- dence from an employee’s residential mailbox.
(UD) Mail Updates (
) Undeliverable (UD) mail is any IRS outgoing mail piece that the USPS deliver to a speciﬁed, domestic address or to a valid forwarding address. (
) Foreign postal services are not obligated to return mail if it cannot be within their areas of delivery. (

) Reasons for non-delivery may include: a. Incomplete, illegible, or incorrect address b. Forwarding order expired c. Addressee is not at address (unknown, moved, or deceased) d. Attempted not known, unable to forward e. Not deliverable as addressed - return to sender f. Box closed unable to forward (
) USPS only provides mail forwarding orders for a period of

months, after which time the order will expire. For six months immediately following expira- tion, mail sent to the taxpayer at the old address will be returned to the with a yellow label showing the new address, and the reason for non-delivery. (
) USPS sends all UD First Class Mail to the IRS return address on the mail piece unless IRS indicates the mail piece may be securely destroyed. (
) The address on the yellow label is the taxpayer’s current address of record the USPS system. (
) The taxpayer provided the USPS with a Change of Address (COA) that from the address used by the IRS. (
) Foreign postal services do not notify a mailer that a change in address has occurred. Address (

) IRS and USPS each have their own COA processes with safeguards to prevent identity theft and misuse of address information. As a result, address data on individuals between the two may differ. An address may be changed by information received from the United States Postal Service, National Change of Address database (NCOA database). As provided in Treas. Reg.§
), an address obtained from the NCOA database becomes taxpayer’s last known address unless the taxpayer provides clear and concise notiﬁcation of a change of address (as set out in Rev. Proc.
) or Service properly processes a taxpayer’s federal income tax return with a different address. Undeliverable (

) Upon receipt of any UD mail piece with an affixed USPS Yellow Label, an office should examine and appropriately research, as follows: a. If the taxpayer’s name printed in the letter and what is shown on the “Yellow Label” are exactly the same, update the taxpayer address to “Yellow Label” address. b. If the taxpayer’s mailing address differs from the “Yellow Label” and name printed on the “Yellow Label” is an exact match to the correspon- dence, update the taxpayer’s mailing address to the “Yellow Label” address. Reissue the correspondence to the taxpayer’s updated mailing address.
Mail and Transportation Management
1.22 Mail and Transportation Management
(1) Undeliverable (UD) mail is any IRS outgoing mail piece that the USPS cannot deliver to a speciﬁed, domestic address or to a valid forwarding address.

USPS only provides mail forwarding orders for a period of 12 months, after which time the order will expire. For six months immediately following expira- tion, mail sent to the taxpayer at the old address will be returned to the sender with a yellow label showing the new address, and the reason for non-delivery.
Upon receipt of any UD mail piece with an affixed USPS Yellow Label, an IRS office should examine and appropriately research, as follows:

a. If the taxpayer’s name printed in the letter and what is shown on the “Yellow Label” are exactly the same, update the taxpayer address to the “Yellow Label” address. b. If the taxpayer’s mailing address differs from the “Yellow Label” and the name printed on the “Yellow Label” is an exact match to the correspon
dence, update the taxpayer’s mailing address to the “Yellow Label” address. Reissue the correspondence to the taxpayer’s updated mailing address.

c. If the taxpayer ﬁrst name is like that on the “Yellow Label”, but the last name is an exact match, conﬁrm whether IRS records show any other taxpayers with similar ﬁrst names and the exact same last name at the same address. If not, update the taxpayer address. Otherwise, do not update the taxpayer address. d. In all other cases do not update the taxpayer address. (

) Where the business unit requires further efforts to obtain a current address, actions may be initiated that include, but are not limited to: • Using the Locator Services System - Address Research (LSS-ADR) to issue Letter
, We Need Your Assistance in Updating Your Address Information, commonly known as “R U There?” to obtain the taxpayer’s current mailing address, if applicable, or • Preparing/issuing IDRS Letter
C, Undeliverable Mail - New Address Veriﬁcation to request veriﬁcation and provide the appropriate change address form. Include a copy of the appropriate Form
, Change Address, when returning correspondence.
Where the business unit requires further efforts to obtain a current address, actions may be initiated that include, but are not limited to:
Using the Locator Services System - Address Research (LSS-ADR) to issue Letter
, We Need Your Assistance in Updating Your Address Information, commonly known as “R U There?” to obtain the taxpayer’s current mailing address, if applicable, or Preparing/issuing IDRS Letter
C, Undeliverable Mail - New Address Veriﬁcation to request veriﬁcation and provide the appropriate change of address form. Include a copy of the appropriate Form
, Change of Address, when returning correspondence.
